SEARCH
Package gw.api.web

Class SessionVar<T>

java.lang.Object
gw.api.web.SessionVar<T>
public class SessionVar<T> extends Object
The value assigned to an instance of this class is stored in the HttpSession that is currently in scope, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. In some execution contexts, such as inside a batch process, a session is not available and accessing an instance of this class will result in an IllegalStateException. Use isRequestAvailable() to detect that situation (the HttpSession is obtained from the HttpRequest).

Be careful when using SessionVar, since it can often lead to memory leaks or code executing in parallel clobbering each other's variable state. RequestVar is preferred for most usages of these two classes.

See below for a typical usage of a SessionVar. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MySessionVar static property for ease of use.

The SessionVar instance contains the key that is used to set and lookup the value of the variable in the HttpSession. You cannot control which key is used, and so you must provide static access to the same SessionVar to access its value from different parts of the application. Note that although the property is static, that's only to hold the SessionVar and its key. Getting and setting the value will be done in the current HttpSession, and so will be unique to each logged in user. 

   // Assign a value to the session variable
   MyClass.MySessionVar = "hello"

   // Access the session variable
   print( MyClass.MySessionVar )

   class MyClass {
     static var _varStoredInSession = new SessionVar()

     static property get MySessionVar() : String {
       if ( _varStoredInSession.RequestAvailable ) {
         return _varStoredInSession.get()
       } else {
         return null
       }
     }
     static property set MySessionVar( value: String ) {
       if ( _varStoredInSession.RequestAvailable ) {
         _varStoredInSession.set( value )
       }
     }
   }
WARNING: the implementation is not thread-safe, but it is highly unusual for multiple threads to deal with the same request or multiple threads deal with multiple requests for the same session.

    • isRequestAvailable

      public boolean isRequestAvailable()
      Returns True if it is safe to call get() and set(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception.

      Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, batch processes execute independent of a request.

      Returns:
      True if an HTTP request is currently in context, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. Otherwise false.
